reveal_title: HEAD TO THE BREAKING POINT LLC RAGE ROOM
bonus: Bring your own music to jam out to!
summary_blurb: Smash stuff together in a rage room for a one-of-a-kind date.
steps: Book a couples session online at The Breaking Point LLC
Wear closed-toe shoes and long pants — they provide safety gear
Pick your smash package and choose extras like glass items or electronics
Blast your own playlist and go wild for 15-30 minutes
Cool down with drinks at a nearby Fox River brewery
notes: Book at least a few days ahead — weekend slots fill up
Minimum age is typically 12+ with a waiver
Combo packages for two are the best value

reveal_title: TAKE THE CAVE POINT TOUR WITH DOOR COUNTY ADVENTURE RAFTING
bonus: Have a picnic afterwards at Baileys Harbor Ridges County Park!
summary_blurb: Explore Lake Michigan's dramatic sea caves by inflatable raft.
steps: Reserve the Cave Point Tour online — morning slots get calmer water
Meet at the launch site and get fitted with gear
Paddle through sea caves and along the rocky shoreline with your guide
After the tour, drive to Baileys Harbor Ridges County Park for a picnic
Hike the boardwalk through the ridges to stretch your legs
notes: Tours run June through September depending on weather
Dress to get wet — bring a change of clothes
WI state park sticker may be required for nearby parks

reveal_title: HIKE THE BALANCED ROCK TRAIL AT DEVIL'S LAKE STATE PARK
bonus: Spend time swimming and having a picnic at the beach!
summary_blurb: Tackle one of Wisconsin's best bluff hikes with incredible lake views.
steps: Arrive early to snag parking at the north shore lot
Start on the East Bluff Trail and hike up to Balanced Rock
Continue along the bluff for panoramic views of the lake
Loop back down via the CCC Trail or Grottos Trail
Cool off with a swim at the north shore beach
notes: $13 daily vehicle pass or annual WI state park sticker required
The bluff trails have steep rocky sections — wear sturdy shoes
Weekends are packed in summer — arrive before 9 AM

reveal_title: KAYAK THE APOSTLE ISLANDS SEA CAVES
bonus: Explore downtown Bayfield and grab fresh whitefish at a local spot!
summary_blurb: Paddle through carved sandstone sea caves on Lake Superior.
steps: Book a guided sea cave kayak tour with a Bayfield outfitter
Check the weather — tours require calm lake conditions
Gear up and paddle out to the mainland sea caves
Explore sandstone arches, chambers, and colorful rock faces
After the tour, walk the Bayfield waterfront and grab lunch
notes: Book well in advance — summer tours sell out fast
Tours depend on Lake Superior conditions and may cancel
Plan for a full day — the drive to Bayfield is part of the adventure

reveal_title: MOUNTAIN BIKE THE CAMBA TRAILS TOGETHER
bonus: Reward yourselves with a burger and a beer in Cable afterwards!
summary_blurb: Ride world-class singletrack through the Chequamegon National Forest.
steps: Rent mountain bikes in Cable if you don't have your own
Start with the Rock Lake or Short & Fat trail for intermediate riding
Ride through hardwood forests, rolling hills, and lakeside terrain
Take a break at a scenic overlook and refuel with snacks
Clean up and head into town for a post-ride meal
notes: Trails are free — donations support maintenance
Check CAMBA trail reports before going
Best riding is June through October

reveal_title: EXPLORE HISTORIC DOWNTOWN CEDARBURG
bonus: Stop at the Cedar Creek Winery in the old woolen mill!
summary_blurb: Wander a charming small-town Main Street full of shops, art, and wine.
steps: Start on Washington Avenue and browse independent shops and galleries
Visit the Cedar Creek Settlement — a restored 1864 woolen mill with a winery
Do a wine tasting at Cedar Creek Winery
Walk to the last covered bridge in Wisconsin at Covered Bridge Park
Grab lunch or coffee at one of the downtown cafes
notes: Free street parking — fills up on festival weekends
The town hosts seasonal festivals — check the event calendar
Most shops open 10-5 daily

reveal_title: TAKE THE LEINENKUGEL'S BREWERY TOUR
bonus: Walk the Chippewa River State Trail along the water afterwards!
summary_blurb: Tour one of America's oldest breweries and sample the lineup.
steps: Head to the Leinenkugel's Brewery & Leinie Lodge in Chippewa Falls
Sign up for the brewery tour — walk-ins welcome, check seasonal hours
Tour the brewing facility and learn the 150+ year history
Enjoy free samples in the tasting room
notes: Tours are free — samples included
Must be 21+ for tastings with valid ID
Pair with a walk on the Chippewa River State Trail nearby

reveal_title: RENT A PONTOON AND CRUISE THE EAGLE RIVER CHAIN OF LAKES
bonus: Pack a cooler and anchor at a sandy beach for a swim break!
summary_blurb: Cruise the world's largest chain of inland lakes on your own pontoon.
steps: Reserve a pontoon rental from a local marina in Eagle River
Get a quick orientation and pick up a lake map
Cruise through the 28-lake chain connected by channels and rivers
Anchor at a sandy beach or island for a swim break
Spot eagles, loons, and herons along the way
notes: Half-day and full-day rentals available — book ahead for weekends
Bring sunscreen, towels, and a cooler with snacks
No boating license required for pontoons

reveal_title: FLOAT THE CHIPPEWA RIVER ON INNER TUBES
bonus: Grab tacos and margaritas at a downtown spot after your float!
summary_blurb: Lazy-river tubing through town — bring snacks and drift.
steps: Rent tubes from a local outfitter near Phoenix Park
Launch at the upstream put-in and float the Chippewa River
Drift through the middle of town for 1-2 hours
Exit at the designated take-out point
Walk to a downtown restaurant for food and drinks
notes: Tubing depends on weather and water levels
Wear water shoes — some sections have rocky bottoms
Best from June through August

reveal_title: DRIVE THE TRACK AT ROAD AMERICA
bonus: Cool off with a swim in Elkhart Lake at the public beach!
summary_blurb: Get behind the wheel on one of America's premier racetracks.
steps: Book a driving experience at Road America in Elkhart Lake
Attend the safety briefing and meet your instructor
Take laps on the legendary 4-mile road course
After the track, drive into Elkhart Lake village for lunch by the water
notes: Experiences range from go-karts ($) to supercars ($$$)
Must have a valid driver's license and closed-toe shoes
Check event calendar — race weekends may limit public access

reveal_title: STROLL LAKESIDE PARK AND VISIT THE LIGHTHOUSE
bonus: Rent a paddleboat on the lagoon!
summary_blurb: Walk through a lakeside park with a lighthouse, gardens, and a lagoon.
steps: Park at Lakeside Park along Lake Winnebago
Walk out to the historic lighthouse at the end of the pier
Stroll through the flower gardens and along the paved paths
Rent a paddleboat on the lagoon if weather allows
Grab ice cream from a nearby spot and enjoy it in the park
notes: The park and lighthouse walk are free
Paddleboat rentals are seasonal — summer only
Nice sunset spot facing Lake Winnebago

reveal_title: HIKE THE TREMPEALEAU NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE
bonus: Stop at the historic Trempealeau Hotel for a walleye dinner!
summary_blurb: Walk through marshlands and bluffs along the Mississippi River.
steps: Drive to the Trempealeau National Wildlife Refuge visitor area
Pick up a trail map and start on the Prairie or Marsh Trail
Watch for bald eagles, herons, and other wildlife along the river
Drive the 4.5-mile wildlife auto tour loop for more scenery
Head to nearby Trempealeau for dinner at the historic hotel
notes: The refuge is free and open dawn to dusk
Bring binoculars for birding
Trails can be muddy in spring — wear appropriate footwear

reveal_title: TAKE A LAMBEAU FIELD STADIUM TOUR
bonus: Visit the NEW Zoo & Adventure Park!
summary_blurb: Go behind the scenes at the legendary home of the Green Bay Packers.
steps: Book the Lambeau Field Stadium Tour online or at the Packers Pro Shop
Walk through the player tunnel onto the field
Visit the luxury suites, press box, and Packers Hall of Fame
Browse the Packers Pro Shop for gear
Grab lunch at one of the restaurants inside the Lambeau Atrium
notes: Tours run year-round but schedules vary on game days
The Hall of Fame is included with the tour or available separately
Allow 60-90 minutes for the full tour

reveal_title: VISIT WILDERNESS WALK ZOO AND EXPLORE DOWNTOWN HAYWARD
bonus: Grab a giant scoop at West's Hayward Dairy on your way out!
summary_blurb: Walk among free-roaming deer and native animals in a northwoods zoo.
steps: Head to Wilderness Walk on the south end of Hayward
Walk the wooded paths and feed the free-roaming deer and animals
Check out the baby animal nursery if visiting in early summer
Drive into downtown Hayward and take a photo at the National Fresh Water Fishing Hall of Fame muskie
Cool down with ice cream at a local dairy shop
notes: Open seasonally — typically mid-May through Labor Day
Bring quarters for the animal feed dispensers
Great for a relaxed afternoon — plan about 2 hours

reveal_title: HIKE TO THE SCENIC TOWER AT HOLY HILL
bonus: Visit the gift shop and grab a bag of monastery caramels!
summary_blurb: Climb the scenic tower at a hilltop basilica for panoramic views of the Kettle Moraine.
steps: Drive to the Basilica of the National Shrine of Mary at Holy Hill
Climb the scenic tower for 360-degree views of the Kettle Moraine
Walk the grounds and the outdoor Stations of the Cross trail
Visit the gift shop inside the basilica
notes: The scenic tower requires a small fee — grounds are free
Fall colors from the tower are spectacular (late September-October)
Dress respectfully for the basilica — it's an active church

reveal_title: WANDER THE ROTARY BOTANICAL GARDENS
bonus: Pack a picnic and enjoy it in the garden's designated area!
summary_blurb: Stroll through 20 acres of themed gardens with international flair.
steps: Head to Rotary Botanical Gardens on the south side of Janesville
Pick up a garden map and wander through the themed sections
Explore the Japanese Garden, English Cottage Garden, and Sunken Garden
Find a quiet bench and enjoy the scenery together
notes: Admission is free — donations appreciated
Peak bloom is June through September
Holiday light show runs in winter if you visit off-season

reveal_title: TOUR THE KOHLER DESIGN CENTER AND EXPLORE THE VILLAGE
bonus: Treat yourselves to lunch at one of the Kohler restaurants!
summary_blurb: See stunning kitchen and bath designs in a free museum-like showroom.
steps: Start at the Kohler Design Center on Highland Drive
Browse three floors of kitchen, bath, and design exhibits
Check out the art gallery and Kohler history displays
Walk through the manicured Kohler village streets
Stop for a nice lunch at one of the village restaurants
notes: The Design Center is free and open Monday-Saturday
The village of Kohler has a planned-community charm worth walking
Pair with a trip to Kohler-Andrae State Park 15 minutes east

reveal_title: HIKE GRANDAD BLUFF FOR A SUNSET VIEW
bonus: Grab dinner at a restaurant on the river after the hike!
summary_blurb: Climb to the top of Grandad Bluff for sweeping views of the Mississippi River valley.
steps: Drive up to Grandad Bluff Park (you can also hike from the base)
Walk to the main overlook for a panoramic view of three states
Hike the bluff trails if you want more exploration
Time it for golden hour if you can — the sunset is incredible
Head downtown to a Mississippi River restaurant for dinner
notes: Free parking at the top — the road is steep but paved
The overlook gets crowded at sunset on weekends
Bring layers — it's windy at the top

reveal_title: TAKE A SCENIC BOAT CRUISE ON GENEVA LAKE
bonus: Walk part of the 21-mile lakeside Shore Path afterwards!
summary_blurb: Cruise past historic estates and beautiful shoreline on Geneva Lake.
steps: Book a cruise with Lake Geneva Cruise Line at the Riviera Docks
Choose a narrated tour — the full lake tour or a mailboat tour
Sit back and enjoy the historic mansions and scenery from the water
After the cruise, stroll the lakeside Shore Path
Browse the shops and restaurants along Main Street
notes: The mailboat tour (with the famous jumping mail carrier) runs in summer
Book ahead for weekend cruises
Evening cruises are available in peak season

reveal_title: VISIT THE OLBRICH BOTANICAL GARDENS
bonus: Grab Thai food on Atwood Avenue after your visit!
summary_blurb: Wander 16 acres of outdoor gardens and a tropical conservatory.
steps: Head to Olbrich Botanical Gardens on the east side of Madison
Walk through the outdoor gardens — the rose garden and rock garden are highlights
Step inside the Bolz Conservatory for a tropical escape (small fee)
Sit by the lakefront garden area and enjoy the view of Lake Monona
notes: Outdoor gardens are free — the conservatory has a small admission fee
The conservatory is open year-round (great winter date)
Holiday light show in December

reveal_title: EXPLORE THE DANE COUNTY FARMERS' MARKET ON THE CAPITOL SQUARE
bonus: Take a free tour of the Wisconsin State Capitol building!
summary_blurb: Browse the largest producer-only farmers' market in the country.
steps: Head to Capitol Square on a Saturday morning (market runs April-November)
Walk the full loop around the Capitol — grab cheese curds, pastries, and flowers
Pick up fresh produce, bread, and a bouquet
Take a free tour of the State Capitol building (offered on the hour)
Grab brunch at a nearby restaurant on the square
notes: Saturday market runs 6:15 AM-1:45 PM, April through November
Arrive early for the best selection and easier parking
Bring cash — not all vendors accept cards

reveal_title: WALK TO PICNIC POINT AND HANG OUT AT THE MEMORIAL UNION TERRACE
bonus: Get Babcock Hall ice cream from the UW Dairy Store!
summary_blurb: A lakeside walk to a secluded peninsula followed by Terrace hangs.
steps: Park near the Lakeshore Nature Preserve and walk out to Picnic Point
Follow the 0.7-mile path through woods to the tip of the peninsula
Find a fire pit or bench and enjoy the views of Lake Mendota
Walk back and head to the Memorial Union Terrace
Grab Babcock Hall ice cream or a pitcher and watch the sunset
notes: Both are free — bring your own snacks or buy at the Terrace
The Terrace has live music many summer evenings
Picnic Point has fire pits available first-come, first-served

reveal_title: BROWSE THE CHAZEN MUSEUM OF ART AND WALK STATE STREET
bonus: Try a different cuisine at one of State Street's many restaurants!
summary_blurb: Free world-class art museum followed by a walk down Madison's iconic street.
steps: Start at the Chazen Museum of Art on the UW campus — admission is free
Explore the permanent collection spanning centuries and cultures
Check for rotating exhibits and any evening events
Walk down State Street, browsing bookshops and boutiques
Pick a restaurant for dinner — the options span every cuisine
notes: The Chazen is free and open year-round (closed Mondays)
State Street is pedestrian-only between the Capitol and campus
Evenings on State Street are lively — restaurants, bars, and live music

reveal_title: TOUR THE SUBMARINE AT THE WISCONSIN MARITIME MUSEUM
bonus: Walk the Manitowoc Riverwalk along the harbor afterwards!
summary_blurb: Explore a real WWII submarine and Lake Michigan maritime history.
steps: Head to the Wisconsin Maritime Museum in downtown Manitowoc
Tour the USS Cobia — a WWII submarine docked right outside
Explore the museum exhibits on Great Lakes shipping and shipbuilding
Walk the Manitowoc Riverwalk along the harbor
notes: Submarine tour is included with museum admission
The submarine has tight spaces — not for the claustrophobic
Allow about 2 hours for the museum and sub tour

reveal_title: RIDE THE FREE MERRIMAC FERRY AND HIKE PARFREY'S GLEN
bonus: Stop for a burger and a shake in Merrimac after your hike!
summary_blurb: Take a free car ferry across the Wisconsin River, then hike a hidden canyon.
steps: Drive to the Merrimac Ferry landing and ride across the Wisconsin River (free!)
Drive to Parfrey's Glen State Natural Area (15 min from the ferry)
Hike the 1.5-mile trail into the glen — a narrow canyon with waterfalls
Wade through the creek crossings together (wear shoes that can get wet)
Take the ferry back and grab food in Merrimac
notes: The ferry runs April through November, dawn to dusk
Parfrey's Glen trail is rocky and wet — wear sturdy waterproof shoes
State park pass required for the glen parking lot

reveal_title: EXPLORE THE HISTORIC THIRD WARD AND MILWAUKEE PUBLIC MARKET
bonus: Catch a show at the Milwaukee Rep or Pabst Theater!
summary_blurb: Browse the Public Market, boutique shops, and galleries in Milwaukee's coolest neighborhood.
steps: Start at the Milwaukee Public Market — grab a snack or coffee
Browse the specialty food vendors and pick up treats to share
Walk through the Third Ward's art galleries and boutique shops
Stroll along the Milwaukee Riverwalk
Grab dinner or drinks at one of the neighborhood's restaurants
notes: The Public Market is open daily — weekday mornings are less crowded
Street parking and nearby garages available
The neighborhood hosts summer festivals and gallery nights

reveal_title: TAKE THE LAKEFRONT BREWERY TOUR
bonus: Walk the lakefront trail along Lake Michigan after the tour!
summary_blurb: The most entertaining brewery tour in Wisconsin — with polka.
steps: Book the Lakefront Brewery tour online (they sell out)
Show up and enjoy the high-energy, comedy-filled tour
Sample four beers included with your tour ticket
Browse the merch shop and grab a souvenir glass
Walk the lakefront trail or explore the nearby Beerline Trail
notes: Book online — Friday and Saturday tours sell out fast
Must be 21+ with valid ID
The tour is known for being fun and entertaining, not stuffy

reveal_title: VISIT THE MILWAUKEE ART MUSEUM
bonus: Watch the Burke Brise Soleil wings open or close at 10 AM, noon, or closing!
summary_blurb: World-class art in a building that's a work of art itself.
steps: Head to the Milwaukee Art Museum on the lakefront
Time your visit to see the Burke Brise Soleil wings open or close
Explore the permanent collection — over 30,000 works
Check the calendar for special exhibitions
Walk the lakefront path or War Memorial plaza afterwards
notes: Wings open at 10 AM, fold at noon, reopen, close at museum closing
Check for free admission days and evening events
The building itself (designed by Calatrava) is worth the visit

reveal_title: DO A GALLERY WALK AND VISIT A CRAFT BREWERY IN MINERAL POINT
bonus: Check if a live glass-blowing demo is happening at Brewery Pottery!
summary_blurb: Browse artist studios, galleries, and a brewery in Wisconsin's most artistic small town.
steps: Start on High Street and wander through the artist galleries and studios
Watch artists at work — many studios are open to visitors
Visit Pendarvis, the restored Cornish miners' village (seasonal)
Head to a local brewery for a craft beer and a bite
notes: Gallery Night events happen several times a year — check the calendar
Many studios close on weekdays — weekends are best for visiting
The town has deep Cornish mining history worth exploring

reveal_title: SPEND THE DAY AT WILDWOOD WILDLIFE PARK AND ZOO
bonus: Rent a kayak or canoe on Lake Minocqua afterwards!
summary_blurb: Feed giraffes, ride camels, and meet hundreds of animals at a northwoods zoo.
steps: Head to Wildwood Wildlife Park & Nature Center in Minocqua
Walk through the park and interact with the animals — many are feed-friendly
Check the schedule for feeding times and animal encounters
Take the safari ride if available
Cool off with a swim or kayak rental on Lake Minocqua
notes: Open seasonally — typically mid-May through late September
Bring cash for animal food and extras
Plan 2-3 hours for the full park

reveal_title: EXPLORE CAVE OF THE MOUNDS AND THE TROLLWAY
bonus: Walk through downtown Mount Horeb and spot all the troll sculptures!
summary_blurb: Tour a dazzling underground cave and walk a troll-themed trail.
steps: Drive to Cave of the Mounds west of Mount Horeb
Take the guided cave tour through the limestone formations
Explore the aboveground gardens and rock displays
Head into Mount Horeb and walk the Trollway — spot all the troll sculptures
Browse the Scandinavian-themed shops on Main Street
notes: The cave is a constant 50°F — bring a light jacket
Open year-round — a great winter date option
Allow about 1 hour for the cave tour

reveal_title: GO ON A GUIDED ATV TOUR THROUGH THE CASTLE ROCK LAKE WISCONSIN AREA
bonus: Rent kayaks or paddle boards and hit the water afterwards!
summary_blurb: Tear through trails on a guided ATV tour near Castle Rock Lake.
steps: Book a guided ATV tour with a local outfitter near New Lisbon
Get a safety briefing and gear up
Ride through wooded trails and open terrain around the Castle Rock area
After the ride, head to Castle Rock Lake for water activities
Rent kayaks or paddleboards and spend time on the water
notes: Must be 16+ with valid ID to drive an ATV on most tours
Wear long pants, closed-toe shoes, and be ready to get dusty
Book ahead — guided tours have limited group sizes

reveal_title: GEEK OUT AT THE EAA AVIATION MUSEUM
bonus: Check if any flight experiences or simulator rides are available!
summary_blurb: Walk among historic aircraft and dream about the sky together.
steps: Head to the EAA Aviation Museum south of Oshkosh
Explore over 200 aircraft including WWII warbirds and homebuilts
Check out the flight simulators and hands-on exhibits
Walk through the Eagle Hangar for the military aviation collection
Browse the museum shop for aviation gifts
notes: Open year-round — great rainy-day date
The EAA AirVenture air show is held here annually in late July
Allow at least 2 hours to see everything

reveal_title: VISIT PEPIN VILLAGE AND GET PIE IN STOCKHOLM
bonus: Drive the Great River Road scenic route along the Mississippi!
summary_blurb: Browse a tiny river town and eat some of Wisconsin's best pie.
steps: Drive to Pepin on the Mississippi River via the Great River Road
Walk the small downtown — browse the shops and the Pepin Historical Museum
Drive 3 miles south to Stockholm and visit the Stockholm Pie & General Store
Order a slice (or a whole pie) and enjoy it with a river view
Drive the Great River Road north or south for scenic bluff views
notes: Stockholm Pie is seasonal — check hours before visiting
Pepin is the birthplace of Laura Ingalls Wilder
The Great River Road is especially beautiful in fall

reveal_title: TOUR THE NATIONAL BREWERY MUSEUM AND POTOSI BREWING
bonus: Drive the Great River Road and stop at the Potosi overlook!
summary_blurb: Explore America's brewing history and taste local brews in a tiny river town.
steps: Head to the National Brewery Museum in Potosi
Tour the museum — it covers the full history of American brewing
Sample beers at the Potosi Brewing Company taproom next door
Check out the transportation museum on the lower level
Drive to a Great River Road overlook for Mississippi views
notes: Museum admission is affordable — check for combo deals with tastings
Potosi is remote — plan it as part of a scenic drive day
The restaurant serves solid pub food

reveal_title: HIKE WYALUSING STATE PARK AND SEE WHERE THE RIVERS MEET
bonus: Visit the Villa Louis historic mansion on St. Feriole Island!
summary_blurb: Stand at the confluence of the Mississippi and Wisconsin Rivers from high bluffs.
steps: Drive to Wyalusing State Park south of Prairie du Chien
Head to Point Lookout for the iconic view of the two rivers meeting
Hike the Sentinel Ridge Trail along the bluff for more viewpoints
Explore the Indian Mounds trail — the park has effigy mounds
Drive into Prairie du Chien and visit Villa Louis if time allows
notes: State park vehicle pass required ($13/day or annual)
The bluffs are spectacular in fall color season
Some trails are steep — wear sturdy shoes

reveal_title: WALK THE DUNES AT KOHLER-ANDRAE STATE PARK
bonus: Grab a Sheboygan bratwurst on the way home — it's the Bratwurst Capital!
summary_blurb: Walk along Lake Michigan beaches and through rare sand dunes.
steps: Drive to Kohler-Andrae State Park south of Sheboygan
Walk the Cordwalk Nature Trail through the dunes and wetlands
Spend time on the beach — it's one of the best on Lake Michigan
Hike the Woodland Dunes Nature Trail for more exploring
Stop for a bratwurst in Sheboygan on the way out
notes: State park vehicle pass required ($13/day or annual)
The beach sand dunes are fragile — stay on marked trails
Lake Michigan water is cold even in summer — but refreshing

reveal_title: EAT AT AL JOHNSON'S (GOATS ON THE ROOF!) AND BIKE DOOR COUNTY
bonus: Grab a cherry pie or cherry wine from a Door County orchard!
summary_blurb: Have Swedish pancakes under a goat-covered roof, then bike through Door County.
steps: Head to Al Johnson's Swedish Restaurant in Sister Bay
Watch the goats grazing on the sod roof while you wait
Order the Swedish pancakes with lingonberries — it's the signature dish
Rent bikes nearby and ride through the scenic countryside
Stop at a cherry orchard or winery along the way
notes: Al Johnson's is cash-only (or check) — no credit cards
Expect a wait on summer weekends — it's worth it
The goats are on the roof from spring through fall

reveal_title: GET LOST IN THE HOUSE ON THE ROCK
bonus: Grab dinner at the Shed in Spring Green after your visit!
summary_blurb: Explore one of Wisconsin's most bizarre and fascinating attractions.
steps: Drive to House on the Rock south of Spring Green
Choose how many sections to explore — there are three to walk through
Marvel at the Infinity Room, the world's largest carousel, and the bizarre collections
Take your time — there's no rushing through this place
Stop in Spring Green for dinner afterwards
notes: Allow 3-4 hours if you want to see all three sections
Tickets are sold by section — Section 1 is the must-see
The Infinity Room extends 218 feet over the valley — not for those afraid of heights

reveal_title: TAKE A GUIDED TOUR OF TALIESIN — FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT'S HOME
bonus: Drive to Tower Hill State Park nearby for a quick bluff hike!
summary_blurb: Tour the home, studio, and estate of America's most famous architect.
steps: Book a tour at Taliesin in advance — several tour options available
Take the guided tour through Wright's home, studio, and grounds
Learn about Wright's design philosophy and his connection to the Wisconsin landscape
Explore the gift shop and visitor center
Drive to nearby Tower Hill State Park for a short bluff hike with river views
notes: Tours are seasonal — typically May through October
Book in advance — popular tours sell out
Different tour levels are available at different price points

reveal_title: BIKE OR HIKE THE GREEN CIRCLE TRAIL
bonus: Tour the Stevens Point Brewery (one of Wisconsin's oldest) afterwards!
summary_blurb: Follow a 26-mile loop trail through woods, rivers, and prairies.
steps: Park at Pfiffner Pioneer Park or another trailhead along the Green Circle
Hike or bike a section of the 26-mile loop through varied terrain
Cross the Wisconsin River and enjoy the riverside stretches
Pick a section that matches your energy — some are paved, some are woodsy
End at a local restaurant or the Stevens Point Brewery for refreshments
notes: The trail is free and open year-round
Some segments are unpaved — check conditions if biking
The Standing Rocks segment has great geological features

reveal_title: DRIVE THE GREAT RIVER ROAD AND EXPLORE TINY STOCKHOLM
bonus: Stop at every scenic overlook and take photos of the Mississippi bluffs!
summary_blurb: Cruise one of America's most scenic drives and explore a village of 66 people.
steps: Start your Great River Road drive from wherever you're coming from
Stop at scenic overlooks along the Mississippi River bluffs
Pull into Stockholm — population 66 — and browse the art galleries
Visit the Stockholm Pie & General Store for homemade pie
Continue your drive north or south along the river
notes: Stockholm shops and bakeries are seasonal — check hours
The drive is gorgeous in fall color season (late September-October)
Combine with Pepin (3 miles north) for a full day trip

reveal_title: PADDLE THE YAHARA RIVER TOGETHER
bonus: Explore downtown Stoughton's Norwegian-themed Main Street!
summary_blurb: Canoe or kayak a gentle river through farmland and wetlands.
steps: Rent canoes or kayaks from a local outfitter in Stoughton
Launch on the Yahara River and paddle downstream
Float through wetlands, farmland, and gentle stretches
Watch for herons, turtles, and other wildlife along the banks
Walk downtown Stoughton's Main Street for a Norwegian-themed vibe
notes: The river is calm and beginner-friendly
Bring sunscreen and water — there's no shade on the river
Best paddling is June through September

reveal_title: HIT THE DOOR COUNTY WINE TRAIL
bonus: End the day with a fish boil at a Door County restaurant!
summary_blurb: Sip your way through scenic Door County wineries.
steps: Start in Sturgeon Bay and pick 2-3 wineries from the Door County Wine Trail
Do tastings at each stop — each winery has its own vibe and specialties
Grab cheese and crackers to share between stops
Enjoy the vineyard scenery and waterfront locations
End the day with a traditional Door County fish boil for dinner
notes: Designate a driver or use a tour service
Most wineries are open spring through fall — check individual hours
Fish boils are a Door County tradition — look for the outdoor boilover show

reveal_title: HIKE TO BIG MANITOU FALLS — WISCONSIN'S TALLEST WATERFALL
bonus: Drive across the Bong Bridge to Duluth for dinner with a harbor view!
summary_blurb: See Wisconsin's highest waterfall plunge 165 feet through a gorge.
steps: Drive to Pattison State Park south of Superior
Follow the short trail to the Big Manitou Falls overlook
Take in the 165-foot waterfall — the tallest in Wisconsin
Hike the trail to Little Manitou Falls for a second waterfall
If time allows, cross into Duluth, MN for dinner
notes: State park vehicle pass required ($13/day or annual)
The falls are most impressive in spring and after rain
The trail to the falls is short but has stairs

reveal_title: CANOE THE NAMEKAGON RIVER THROUGH THE NATIONAL SCENIC RIVERWAY
bonus: Pack a picnic and pull over at a sandbar for a riverside lunch!
summary_blurb: Paddle a wild, pristine river through the St. Croix National Scenic Riverway.
steps: Book a canoe or kayak rental with shuttle service from a Trego outfitter
Get dropped off upstream and paddle back to the outfitter
Drift through old-growth forest and sandy banks
Pull over at a sandbar for a swim or picnic break
Watch for bald eagles, otters, and turtles along the way
notes: The river is calm and great for beginners
Bring waterproof bags for phones and snacks
Book trips in advance for summer weekends

reveal_title: HIKE AND BEACH-HOP AT POINT BEACH STATE FOREST
bonus: Visit the Point Beach lighthouse — one of the oldest on Lake Michigan!
summary_blurb: Walk miles of Lake Michigan shoreline through dunes and forest.
steps: Drive to Point Beach State Forest north of Two Rivers
Start with the Rawley Point Trail along the Lake Michigan shore
Walk the beach and hunt for beach glass and interesting rocks
Visit the Rawley Point Lighthouse (exterior viewing)
Hike the Red Pine Trail through the interior forest
notes: State park vehicle pass required ($13/day or annual)
The beach is long and uncrowded even in summer
The lighthouse is photogenic but not open for interior tours

reveal_title: HIKE RIB MOUNTAIN FOR PANORAMIC VIEWS
bonus: Grab hot cocoa or a meal at a Wausau restaurant after the hike!
summary_blurb: Hike one of the highest points in Wisconsin for sweeping views of the countryside.
steps: Drive to Rib Mountain State Park on the west side of Wausau
Hike the trail to the observation tower at the summit
Take in the panoramic views of the surrounding farmland and forests
Explore the other hiking trails if you want a longer outing
Head into Wausau for food and drinks
notes: State park vehicle pass required ($13/day or annual)
In winter, Granite Peak ski area operates on the mountain
The summit trail is moderate — about 1 mile round trip

reveal_title: GO ON A CLEAR KAYAK GLOW TOUR UNDERNEATH THE STARS!
bonus: Look into their daytime rentals and rent an e-bike, paddleboard, or kayak during the day!
summary_blurb: Paddle lit-up clear kayaks on a crystal-clear lake under the night sky.
steps: Book the Clear Kayak Glow Tour with a Waupaca outfitter in advance
Arrive at sunset and get your gear and safety briefing
Paddle out on crystal-clear water in LED-lit transparent kayaks
Watch the lake bottom light up beneath you as the sky darkens
Float under the stars and enjoy the surreal experience together
notes: Book well in advance — glow tours are extremely popular
Tours are weather-dependent and may cancel for storms
Check if daytime e-bike and paddleboard rentals are available to extend your day

reveal_title: TAKE THE LOST CANYON HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGE TOUR
bonus: Hike the Witches Gulch trail nearby for more canyon views!
summary_blurb: Ride a horse-drawn carriage through the deepest and longest land canyon in Wisconsin.
steps: Head to Lost Canyon Tours on Canyon Road in the Dells
Board a horse-drawn carriage for the guided canyon tour
Ride through towering sandstone walls up to 80 feet high
Enjoy the narrated history and geology of the canyon
After the tour, check out the Witches Gulch trail for more sandstone scenery
notes: Tours run spring through fall — check seasonal hours
The ride takes about 30-45 minutes
Witches Gulch is accessible by Upper Dells Boat Tour — check availability
